Wheat.description: A staple grain used for making bread and flour

Barley.description: A hardy grain used in ale brewing and animal feed

Oats.description: A cereal crop commonly used for porridge and livestock feed

Onions.description: A pungent vegetable used in soups and stews

Leeks.description: A mild-flavored vegetable used in broths and pies

Cabbage.description: A leafy vegetable that stores well for winter

Apples.description: A common orchard fruit eaten fresh or made into cider

Pears.description: A sweet fruit eaten fresh or dried for preservation

Plums.description: A soft fruit used in preserves and dried as prunes

Beans.description: A protein-rich legume used in stews and dry storage

Peas.description: A nutritious crop eaten fresh or dried for winter

Lentils.description: A hardy legume rich in protein and easy to store

Raw Wool.description: Unprocessed wool sheared from sheep for spinning

Spun Wool.description: Wool that has been processed into yarn for weaving

Tanned Hides.description: Animal skins treated to make leather

Leather Goods.description: Items such as belts, boots, and bags made from leather

Sheep.description: Domesticated animals raised for wool and meat

Pigs.description: Livestock raised for pork and lard

Cattle.description: Large livestock used for meat, milk, and labor

Wool Cloth.description: Fabric woven from wool yarn for garments and blankets

Linen.description: Cloth made from flax fibers, used for undergarments and fine wear

Plant-dyed Cloth.description: Fabric colored using natural dyes from plants like woad or madder

Mineral-dyed Cloth.description: Cloth dyed with minerals such as ochre or iron oxide

Logs.description: Cut timber used for fuel or construction

Lumber.description: Sawn wood planks used in building and carpentry

Charcoal Blocks.description: Processed wood used as fuel for blacksmithing and cooking

Jars.description: Clay containers used to store food, liquids, or goods

Tiles.description: Clay-based flat items used for roofing or flooring

Pottery.description: Fired clay vessels for cooking, storage, or trade

Salt Blocks.description: Large chunks of salt used for preserving meats and seasoning

Salt Crystals.description: Granulated salt commonly used in cooking

Granite.description: Hard stone used for roads, monuments, and buildings

Limestone.description: A soft stone used in construction and making mortar

Hoes.description: Farming tools used for weeding and tilling soil

Sickles.description: Curved blades used for harvesting grain and grass

Hammers.description: Tools used in construction and smithing

Swords.description: Bladed weapons crafted by skilled blacksmiths

Chainmail.description: Linked metal armor worn for protection in combat

Rings.description: Ornamental bands worn on fingers, often indicating wealth

Brooches.description: Decorative pins used to fasten cloaks and garments

Beads.description: Small decorative items used in jewelry or traded in bulk

Barrels of Ale.description: Fermented drink made from barley, stored in barrels

Bottles of Mead.description: Alcoholic beverage made from fermented honey

Bottles.description: Glass or ceramic containers for storing liquids

Bowls.description: Round dishes used for eating or mixing food

Saffron.description: A rare and valuable spice harvested from crocus flowers

Pepper.description: Imported spice used to season and preserve food

Cinnamon.description: Sweet spice often used in baked goods and mulled drinks

Honey Jars.description: Containers of sweet bee-made product used in food and mead

Comb Honey.description: Honey still stored in the wax comb, considered a delicacy

Embroidered Tunics.description: Fine clothing decorated with stitched patterns

Silk Trim.description: Expensive fabric used to edge garments, often imported

Illuminated Texts.description: Handwritten books decorated with gold and illustrations

Religious Scrolls.description: Sacred or scholarly writings used by clergy or scholars
